PRESIDENT'S SPEECH

Debate on the Address
(Fifth Day)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [16th October, 1972],

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to: -

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".'.- [Mr Chai Chong Yii].

    Question again proposed.

2.31 p.m.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when we rose yesterday, I was dealing with a matter concerning the equality between duties and rights. In other words, people working in the same place should be governed by the same rules and regulations. When duties and rights are not properly equated, especially under an enlightened Government like ours, they can be said to be an oversight on the

Column: 230

Government's part. For example, on the question of the retirement age for Chinese school teachers, there are two different kinds of ruling. According to the regulations, those who were employed before 1st July, 1956, have to retire at 55 years, while those employed after this date can retire at 60. We feel that this regulation is unreasonable. I wonder why such a regulation should be adopted and why it is still being implemented by the Ministry of Education. I said yesterday that the Singapore Chinese School Teachers' Association had submitted memorandum after memorandum to the Ministry of Education, all of which had been shelved and forgotten. There was no reply to the memoranda submitted so far. Sir, we have made repeated submissions, but they have been simply ignored. This is a matter for regret. It is not my intention to take up so much time of this House in dealing with this small matter. However, I strongly feel that the implementation of the regulations which I have described is causing discontent and dissatisfaction among the teachers in Chinese schools.

Column: 231



    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have always said that teachers in our Republic should inculcate in our children a sense of national consciousness and patriotism. But the Ministry of Education has not looked after the interests of our patriotic teachers. On the contrary, it is giving special treatment to those who are not patriotic and whose loyalty is, in fact, in doubt. You will recall that in 1959 when the present Government first took office with a mandate from the people, it was decided that in order to save our national coffers and our economic resources, there should be a pay cut in the public service. As a result of the pay cut, the teachers suffered. In addition, they had to carry a greater work load. They had to teach in the adult education classes. Teachers in Government-aided schools also suffered the pay cut. When the pay cut order was made, some of the teachers who had no backbone and who were not loyal and patriotic took to their heels and went across the Causeway to offer their services there. In other words, they left the Singapore education service to work elsewhere. Three or four years later, when our national economy took a turn for the better, these people came back to Singapore because the pay cut was restored. However, these people, who left and returned, were classified as teachers employed after 1st July, 1956, and are therefore allowed to carry on teaching happily until they reach the age of 60. Those who did not leave the service then have to retire at 55 under the same regulations. Are we to encourage patriotic feeling by looking after the interests of the determined lot of the teachers who did not take to their heels? Or are we to give better treatment to those who left the service in the face of difficult times? Mr Speaker, Sir, this is a question we have to consider very seriously. We should not allow opportunists to get a better deal.

    I have taken up the question of the retirement age in order to draw the attention of the Minister for Education to this anomaly so that it can be rectified. I hope to hear from the new Minister for Education, the Minister of State,

Column: 232

or the Parliamentary Secretary, declaring that the retiring age for teachers in Singapore would be unified. I am still far away from the age of retirement. Therefore, I am not speaking for my own personal interest, but on behalf of the other teachers. I come under the regulation for retirement at 60. Let us forget these asides which are unnecessary. When I took up this matter I did so in the hope that the memoranda submitted by the Singapore Chinese School Teachers' Association would receive due consideration from the Ministry.

    The last point I wish to raise concerns educative travel. In the President's address, it was stated that grants from the Education Fund would be given for educative travel to enable teachers and students to see the neighbouring countries. This, of course, is a matter for rejoice because it will be of benefit to our teachers and students. It will be an encouragement to our teachers and students to learn by actual experience instead of by rote. What I fail to under-stand, however, is this. Recently the Singapore Chinese School Teachers' Association sent a team of teachers to' attend the Fifth Asian Conference of the Congress of the World Teaching Profession in Tokyo. The Singapore Chinese School Teachers' Association had to' raise its own funds to pay for the passage. They did not receive a single cent from the Government. At the end of the conference they were invited to tour the neighbouring countries. They therefore spent six extra days overseas. What was most exasperating was that for some reason, the Ministry of Education or the Ministry of Finance cut six days of their pay. Instead of receiving, a grant, the teachers suffered a pay cut. Perhaps the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Finance should get together to find out whether educative travel should be encouraged by allowing full-pay leave [Interruption]. If teachers are sent to Taiwan to learn the Chinese language, it is not a bad idea because they are not allowed to go to mainland China.

Column: 233



    Mr Speaker: Mr Tay, please continue with what you want to say, instead of arguing with Members.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I was speaking on educative travel. The point I want to stress here is that since it has become a matter of policy to encourage educative travel, teachers should be given every opportunity to make use of their annual leave for this purpose. Why should teachers suffer a pay cut while they are on educative travel? Mr Speaker, Sir, it is my hope that since educative travel is being encouraged, as mentioned in the President's address, the officials in the Ministry of Education or the Ministry of Finance will take note of this policy and implement it accordingly, instead of treating this as propaganda material. Sir, we are certainly grateful to the President for making it a Government policy to encourage educative travel among the teachers and students. This will certainly widen their horizon. I fully endorse this policy. As to the details of its implementation, we can discuss them at the proper time.

2.45 p.m.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Encik Othman bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to associate myself with the sentiments already expressed by my honourable colleagues in thanking the President for his many timely and thought-provoking statements contained in his Address.

    I have said "timely" because the President has very ably outlined in his Address the change of circumstances that prevail in our Republic today, circumstances which not only differ from those of five years ago but also necessitate a change of planning and action to enable us to face the tasks ahead. The President's Address provides us with many guidelines for the future development of Singapore and which very correctly underline the social principle governing our society, i.e, the principle of sustained collective endeavour and quality participation.

Column: 234



    Today, more than ever, we must evolve social policies which will ensure the full utilisation of our manpower resources, particularly to resolve the shortage of labour in the present employment situation. There is no doubt that, in the years ahead, we must consciously strive to create conditions in which social dislocations will be minimised and the widest opportunity for community participation and individual fulfilment in work or in recreation, is afforded to all our citizens.

    As emphasised in the President's speech, Singaporeans must avoid the pattern of thinking, the welfare state syndrome, where everyone expects others, not himself, to work harder to carry the burden of providing services and amenities which everyone wants. It must be recognised that there is a limit to what the State can provide. In social services, clearly it is not possible nor is it desirable for the Government to do everything. Much could be said about the danger that lurks within the apparently innocent philosophy of "something for nothing", and it is true that in the context of our circumstances in Singapore today this selfish and seemingly harmless philosophy of "something for nothing" could turn out to be disastrous, if not fatal.

    In the field of social affairs, I would be the first to endorse the statement of the President that "no one should get away with enjoying services subsidised through the hard work of others, without making his own contribution, to the best of his ability and capacity." That is why, of late, my Ministry has been reviewing its policies, and is considering new schemes whereby those who can work, though with limitations, should be encouraged, trained and helped along to work. For example, in our Public Assistance Scheme, my officers have been scanning and sieving the lists of public assistance recipients who, on account of their age, physical abilities or circumstances, are believed to be able to do at least some work; and the main guideline in our new policy will be that such public assistance recipients

Column: 235

who can work will be offered suitable employment or, if they are untrained, will be put on training schemes to help them take up gainful employment eventually. We have now reached the stage where, unless valid reasons are given by recipients as to why they cannot accept the job or the training offered, their public assistance allowance will be discontinued if they should turn down offers of employment.

    In the same vein, we are also looking into the intensive and extensive training of the handicapped adults of Singapore. While training of the handicapped by the various voluntary welfare organisations in Singapore has so far been concentrated on the children and teenage groups, not much has been done for the training of the handicapped adults who, for one reason or another, are not able to obtain employment due to their being untrained and handicapped. The Social Welfare Department is at the moment considering all possible measures to provide useful and suitable training for the handicapped adults of Singapore in order to enable them to be well-equipped for employment and to obtain suitable employment. This is a significant step in the rehabilitation of the handicapped people of Singapore, closely following the policy that even the handicapped today are expected to make their own contribution towards society to the best of their ability and capacity.

    In this connection, I wish to make it clear that there is no intention whatsoever on the part of the Government to reduce or cease welfare aid to those who are really incapable and who, on account .of their old age or severe handicap, are unable to make any contribution to the society. We will continue to provide assistance to such unfortunate and genuinely needy citizens, but certainly this "something for nothing" business will not be applied to the able-bodied and the unemployed who due to their sheer laziness or inertia have not been trying to work and who have sought the easiest way out by merely relying on welfare aid. To these people, gone are the days when they could get something for nothing.

Column: 236



    We have over the years evolved a pattern of social services based on the participation of both the Government and the voluntary sectors. It is intended to restructure and strengthen community participation in welfare services by reorganising the various services which have been developed rather haphazardly, depending more on individual initiative and effort, into systematic and planned operations.

    The Government has already taken steps to strengthen the Research and Training Section of the Social Welfare Department, and one of the functions of this Section, apart from its research and training roles, is to engage in systematic planning for the improvement of welfare services in the Republic.

    More sophisticated techniques will be used in the rehabilitation process not only for the residents of welfare homes but also for juvenile offenders placed on probation. A psychologist has already been recruited to launch a Psychological Service and to provide consultancy and referral services in the adjustment programme which in the near future will involve greater participation by voluntary welfare workers.

    I would like to take this opportunity to express my appreciation for the concern shown by the Member for Kuo Chuan regarding the working of the Women's Charter. I would like to assure the Member that from time to time my Ministry makes a study of the problems and the issues posed in the implementation of the Women's Charter. I would like to point out that the Women's Charter is only a legislative measure to prevent abuse, and it has already proven its usefulness by enhancing the status and promoting the welfare of women and families.

    However, I would like to correct the impression created by the Member when he said that the divorce rates had soared to unmanageable heights. In fact, the number of divorce petitions over the last five years has been within the region of 200 to 300 per year, as compared to the number of marriages which is between 10,000 to 13,000 per year.

Column: 237

The Member may also wish to know that from 1960 to 1971 there were only 2,036 applications made to the High Court for divorces, and only 1,411 of these were approved, giving an average of only 128 actual divorce cases per year. Although this figure is higher than that for 1960, i.e., before the introduction of the Women's Charter, where approximately 80 divorces per year were recorded, it must be recognised that in those days most marriages, including polygamous marriages, were not registered and, hence divorce was by mutual consent, the figures for which were not included in statistics given by the High Court. I would like to dispel the impression that divorce can easily be obtained. The provisions for divorce in the Women's Charter are fairly restrictive. It is also interesting to note that the social stigma attached to divorces has now diminished.

    I agree with the Member that due to rapid urbanisation and modernisation, the stabilising forces in our Asian culture, which have kept families together, have been weakened to some extent. There are also many other factors in our social situation that have brought about conflicts and tensions affecting family life. To counteract these trends and tendencies, social education, either in the home or within the school setting, is most important.

    I welcome the Member's suggestion for a review of the Women's Charter. But for such a review to be fruitful, considerable sociological research into the factors affecting family life is necessary. It is for this reason that a Research and Training Section has been set up in the Social Welfare Department, and it is hoped that through the various projects, which have already been planned, it may be possible to know more about the various social phenomena which the Member has pointed out.

    In sports, we have a two-fold objective. Firstly, we must make sport the way of life for our people. Sports can build body and mind, and it is vital to

Column: 238

social peace. The Government has already laid the foundations and indicated the direction for mass participation in sports and games. Inter-constituency sports is promising, and every effort must be made by one and all to sustain it, and the necessary organisation and funds must be obtained to provide a more varied programme and comprehensive range of facilities.

    Equally important, we must aim at excellence in sports. This can only be achieved with the necessary organisation, funds and support in the way of staff, expertise, availability of training time and adequate facilities. There is no doubt that we can succeed, considering that within the short space of one and a half years of the establishment of the National Sports Promotion Board, we have not only paved the way for mass participation in sports but also established the framework for the development of sports talents for both national and international competitions.

    Sometime next year the National Stadium will be the venue for the Seventh SEAP Games, the first time a major international meet of such importance is being organised here. We have already successfully bidden for the next Asian Games to be held in Singapore in 1978. The task of developing the necessary organisation and infrastructure to make Singapore an important centre for sports is a challenging one, but judging from the present leadership, enthusiasm and dedication shown by so many people involved in the organization of sports, I have every confidence that what we have set out to do in sports will soon be realised.

3.05 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Ong Soo Chuan) (in Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the First Session of the Third Parliament since our independence. As our President has pointed out in his speech:

    `We meet today under circumstances vastly different from those prevailing when the last Parliament was convened on 6th May, 1968.'

Column: 239



    In fact, our past era can be reviewed in two stages. The first stage is the period after independence, which was quite a tumultuous one. During that period Singapore became a Republic and there were many problems to be resolved and tackled. The second stage is the five-year period when we were in office. During this time we had to solve many difficulties and problems which were more harsh and real, such as economy, defence, unemployment and the problem of redundancy caused by the British military withdrawal. However, under our judicious leadership with the right policies and with the co-operation and effort of our diligent people, we managed to solve all of them, each and every one.

    Now we are entering into the third stage, in which we strive for quality, and on the basis of our past successful experience, I believe we can achieve results. The central theme of this message of the President is that, in addition to achieving higher standards of education, business management, and work ethic, there are two conditions to be met. One is the establishment of the small family to ensure a better quality and an improved living standard. This will enable the next generation to look after themselves better, without being a burden to the society or the nation. The other condition is the abuse of free social welfare services. We should remember that everybody has a duty to put in his share of work, either physically or mentally, in return for what he wants. In any society, there should be no such thing as getting something for free. Otherwise that country will become either weaker or poorer.

    Singapore has emerged from a period of difficulties, and marching into its eighth year of independence at a steady pace. Through our past efforts in overcoming difficulties, we have gained rich and varied experience, and our people's confidence in building a better society has been strengthened. In not too short a time, we have overcome many difficult problems which, in the eyes of outsiders, were impossible to solve. All this is due to the determination and drive of our

Column: 240

people, which have consolidated the foundation of nation building.

    We managed to overcome the difficulties encountered in the past because most of our adult population had gone through the mill and lived through different social systems. They had gone through suppression by colonial rule and the persecution by the Japanese warlords during the second World War. And finally they had also gone through the relentless treatment of the corrupt government of the early days of a self-governing state. In short, they had gone through trials and tribulations and emerged from the baptism of fire. With all these experiences and efforts they have made sacrifices and struggle to build up their own country and an ideal society. After independence, the people have become masters of their own destiny. This fact has strengthened their patriotism, and because of this they have discarded the feeling of being birds of passage and the attitudes of immigrants. So on this concept they are able to build a further prosperous and progressive society.

    The unique quality about the people of Singapore is that, unlike those of other countries, they have not taken to the belief that just because Singapore is independent they can sit down and enjoy life. If we look at the developing countries around us, we will see that instead of making any advancement they are on the way down. That we have been able' to progress from time to time and become more and more prosperous is all due to the good quality of our people who know that independence does not necessarily bring with it prosperity and progress. The people realise that concerted efforts and hard work on the part of the people will make possible nation building. They do not take chances but instead participate actively in the task of nation building. So long as this patriotic spirit exists among these seasoned adults of Singapore, it will be very difficult for foreign interests to buy over Singapore. But the strength of this adult population cannot last forever. With the passage of time it must gradually dissipate. Therefore, in

Column: 241

order to preserve our hard-won achievements and to ensure that there will be further progress and prosperity for Singapore, we must take preventive measures so that our country under the leadership of the next generation will not be taken over or manipulated by foreign elements. As stated in the Presidential address, Constitutional amendments are necessary to ensure that:

    `no surrender of our sovereignty, or any part thereof, by way of incorporation into, or federation with, any other country is possible, unless two-thirds of the total electorate vote positively for it in a referendum.'

All this is a preparation for a better future. It does not mean that we have no confidence in the next generation of leaders. This is because about 50 per cent of them at least do not have the actual experience of the difficulties and hardships that older leaders had undergone in the past. They lack the experience of the hardships and tribulations of the early `50s. Whatever knowledge they may gather about those difficulties comes from books or hearsay. Most of them have been enjoying modern, stable and comfortable living in Singapore. From childhood to adulthood they have not gone through the mill, as the present generation had. Therefore, we have to give some consideration to this matter. To make good the shortcomings, we must strengthen this feeling of patriotism and the indomitable spirit by laying sufficient stress on education. Education is fundamental to nation building and the running of a country. To make sure that the future leadership from the younger generation will have the same verve and capability of the present leadership, we must see to it that the content and quality of education should he such that these future leaders will not only be able to contribute towards the economic progress of the country hut also maintain political stability with patriotism.

    Let us look around the industrially advanced countries in the world. Many of them have paid attention only to their industrial and economic needs, and not the cultivation of the necessary virtues

Column: 242

and character of their people. As a result there is an imbalance of interests among their people manifesting excessive individualism over nationalism. Some of the young people study hard merely for the sake of getting highly paid jobs so that they can enjoy. Although Singapore is a developing country, in terms of economic growth, she is already a developed country. It is necessary only to enhance the quality of education and to encourage technological education. But if we only crystallise our attention on our economic needs at the expense of the cultivation of patriotic and ethical virtues, then there may come a society steeped in selfishness with a generation of people who only care for themselves without so much care for the country the young leadership will then be weakened. Therefore, for the future of our nation, we must try to arrest the trend of such development. We must actively foster the concept of patriotic virtues among our young people. We must make our young people realise that improvement in the quality of education is not meant to enhance their own selfish personal interest, but for the national interest and for a better service to the society. Hence, the Ministry of Education should positively shoulder up this responsibility.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, over the past few years particularly during the last general elections, there is a clear indication of doubt over the loyalty of some opposition parties. For ideological reasons, some of them are inclined to look up to other countries, others, for their own selfish reasons, have become the Trojan horse in our country; some have become the mouthpiece of foreign interests. On the face of it, such people are very convincing in their talks, but in the final analysis we can see their hideous motives. Mr Speaker, Sir, if our way of life and our policies have not had the strong support of the people, we would not have been able to obtain this landslide victory. The crux of the problem is that there are still some people with ulterior motives who wish to make use of the mass media, both to mislead and to divide our people. They are doing

Column: 243

this in order to satisfy the desire of their foreign masters. So the people of Singapore must always be on guard against such people. Constitutional amendments to ensure our national integrity and sovereignty are therefore very necessary. These measures are also necessary to ensure the political stability and economic prosperity of Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, because of the present political stability, economic prosperity and high standard of living there are some people in our midst who have neither tasted nor realised what hardship is. They are very naive and very foolishly tried to create trouble by interfering with the good life of the people. If history should repeat itself, and if there should be a return of the turbulent days of boycott of classes, strikes, and riots of the `50s and the early `60s, then could we continue to lead this secure, happy and satisfying life? We should, therefore, heighten our vigilance, cultivate our patriotic feelings, examine ourselves and foster the virtue of putting national and public interest above personal interest, and working diligently with others. With concerted effort we must maintain our verve and drive, take up the responsibility and plan carefully for a better future, and make full use of whatever potential we have to meet the challenging roles confronting us in the future.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion.

3.20 p.m.

    Dr Augustine H. H. Tan (Whampoa)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the people of Singapore have voted wisely for political stability, for they know that economic and social progress depends upon a climate of stability and confidence. With such a favourable climate, we can address ourselves to the challenging task of developing our country into a great metropolis, with a cultured, well-educated and highly-skilled population.

    In his distinguished address, our President stressed two essential pre-conditions for Singapore to become a centre

Column: 244

for excellence. The first has to do with family planning. People in the low income group should take particular note of this. They should not handicap themselves further by having more children than they can feed, more children than they can educate, or more children than they can accommodate decently in their one- or two-room flats.

    The second pre-condition the President mentioned, that is, the preservation of the work ethic and discipline, must be taken seriously by all Singaporeans. Parents, in particular, should not overindulge their children with liberal pocket-money or tolerate idleness and indiscipline. When I see students today driving their own cars to the Junior College, or to the University, I sometimes wonder whether parents are not making life too soft for their children. If our youth do not learn the value of money and do not acquire a measure of self-discipline, then our future as a nation is in doubt.

    For the immediate future, our task is to upgrade our industries, improve our technical skills, and acquire more sophisticated managerial and marketing expertise. In the past, we were more concerned with promoting foreign investment than with development as such. In the future, investment promotion must go hand in hand with development of technical and managerial skills. To ensure this, perhaps our industrial incentives could be revised to encourage expansion of existing enterprises, especially local enterprises. Perhaps we can also devise additional criteria for granting tax incentives to industries, e.g, a target number or a proportion of technical and managerial personnel could be specified so as to ensure that proper development of Singaporeans take place.

    One of the constraints to further development of industry is the availability of technical and professional personnel. I believe we should create a pool of such people from abroad by prior screening and granting of provisional permanent visas. Such visas can be exercised when an approved job is available to the applicant. This would cut down delays in recruitment. In

Column: 245

addition, housing needs to be made available to the new immigrant for the initial six months or a year.

    Rapid development requires a corresponding capacity to cope with change. In industry, we shall have to deal with firms made uncompetitive by rising rents and wages or else by urban renewal. We shall have to balance the need for equity with the long-term interests of Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to add my support for the Finance Minister's decision to increase the pay of civil servants. The dedicated efforts of our civil service have been crucial to Singapore's development over the last 14 years. We must recognise and reward the dedicated. Moreover, as the President pointed out, we need to preserve quality in our civil service. I believe we should have periodic reviews of civil service salaries, especially in the context of rapid development.

    I also welcome the Government's policy of taxing luxury consumption. This would encourage saving and discourage lavish consumption which can have bad social effects.

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully endorse the Government's intention of amending our Constitution to prevent Singapore from being bought over by foreign countries.

    I fully support the motion moved by the hon. Member for Bukit Batok.

3.26 p.m.

    Mr Phey Yew Kok (Boon Teck): Mr. Speaker, Sir, I am happy to note that, in the addendum to the President's Speech dealing with the Ministry of Labour, there is a categorical statement to the effect that "workers are human beings and not mere cogs in the wheels of production." If we want a healthy framework of industrial relations to develop in Singapore, it is of fundamental importance that our system of industrial relations should get away from concepts which regard the worker and his skill as no more than yet another

Column: 246

purchasable commodity on the market. Human skills certainly have a market value. But human co-operation cannot be purchased. It can only be earned through the practice of sound industrial psychology.

Instead, there is a system of arbitrary orders, the reasons for which are not given, but which the workers are expected to obey like automatons.
